content:
email folders are on the email server, folders from LOCAL down are on YOUR system.

If you want a folder under your email, most times you have to create that folder where the actual email is. For instance, go to Yahoo mail to make a folder under your email account there, or go to google gmail to make folders under THAT email account.

If you want a folder on YOUR computer, you should have no problem creating a LOCAL folder called " Receipt" Just right-click on "Local" and make a folder under Local. You can also add it under a subfolder as you already did.

creator: James

content: You misread my post are comment.
creator: danbollinger

content:
danbollinger said
You misread my post are comment.

Well I have read it all and to be blunt, I have no idea what the discussion is about. You have changed the port from from 465 to 587 and now I assume you get some sort of sending error. What is it? Clearly it has nothing to do with TLS. Without knowing what the actual error is, offering anything but platitudes is not really an option.

What I do know about the bargain basement solutions offered by network solutions is they fail entirely to offer a valid SSL certificate for the server you are asked to connect to and a manual exception has to be created for each and every host and port used. You I guess have an exception recorder for the old port but not the new. I also have seen a couple of topics suggesting a bug in the request for a certificate not occurring if the password is saved. So I suggest you go to the saved passwords in Thunderbird and delete the saved password for that outgoing account. That should allow the prompt to appear (if my reading between the lines is any good.)
creator: MattAuSupport

content: You should be able to create a local folder and copy messages to the local folder and then delete from server.
creator: davidsk

content:
I suggest you have a looking the certificate manager and identify the certificate you added the exception for. That might offer some clue as the the source of the issue.

Also delete any saved passwords for the account in the password manager. Not having a password may allow the actual error to bubble up to where it can be seen. But I would guess, like you, that the certificate is no longer valid.

Finally what are the settings being used for the outgoing server?

A DNS search for the domain you mention https://intodns.com/edcmeals.com shows the mail exchanger is registered as mail.edcmeals.com. While this may not be the mail submission server, it usually is. A test of the SSL/TLS for the domain using the default encrypted port of 465 got me a result that the mail server is vulnerable to about every serious hack in the last 5 years. It got a F rating https://www.immuniweb.com/ssl/mail.edcmeals.com/2pHva0TL/

I am guessing the main issue of is the size of the key at 1025bits. 2048 has been a basic requirement for the majority of the last 10 years. The logjam vulnerability having come to light in 2015.

Personally I feel the encrypted connection is next to useless in this case. I would suggest you look as using a non encrypted connection to the server if you can do nothing about the general standard of the encryption used.

I look at the whois registry information for the domain https://who.is/whois/edcmeals.com and using the diagnostics there and a traceRT, it looks like the server may be an on premises device, hosted on the old road runner network. If that is the case I strongly suggest some update to the server configuration. It is way out of date with regards to security, at a time of heightened international activity with regard to nation sponsored hacking.

Do this first: On new laptop: Exit Thunderbird Access the Firewall Please make sure that thunderbird.exe program is set up as an allowed program otherwise Firewall may block access meaning thunderbird cannot access the server.

re : I have tried many combinations

There is only one correct set of settings to use. You have to use the correct password and it is exactly the same as the one you use to access webmail account. You have to use the correct email address - no typos - and note the User name = the full email address. You have to use the correct server settings and I would advise you use IMAP because you seem to be accessing the server via various devices. However, spectrum offer different server settings depending upon the email address or more specifically what comes after the '@' in email address.

To help advise you: What comes after the '@' in your email address?

content:
You probably should be using the profile manager and not playing with the ini file.

It may be easier to use the Profile Manager while you're sorting things out.

Maybe create a NEW Profile and use the import function to actually get the old profile working again, and once you have a working Profile, then maybe you can remove the ones you wanted to delete. .

Here's a way to make a shortcut to the Profile Manager If you are using Windows. I see you're not using Windows, so you should be able to adjust these directions for your OS.

1. Right-click on the Thunderbird icon and click "Properties".

NOTE: If your icon is on the taskbar, you may need to right-click again on "Thunderbird" within, then select "Properties".

2. Click on Open File Location.

3. Find Thunderbird.exe and right-click on it, then select Create Shortcut, allowing it to place the shortcut on the Desktop.

4. Right-click on the new Thunderbird Shortcut on the Desktop and select Properties.

5. In the Target field, go to the very end and add -P, then click Apply. The whole line should look something like this;

"C:\Program Files\Mozilla Thunderbird\thunderbird.exe" - P

6. Click the General tab and give the shortcut the name Profile Manager, then press OK.

That will allow you to open the Profile Manager easier while you work on getting things straight.

Additionally, If you end up with more than one profile, you can make more copies of the shortcuts, and after the -P just add another space, then "ProfileNameYouWantToOpen". It should look like;

"C:\Program Files\Mozilla Thunderbird\thunderbird.exe" - P "ProfileName"

content:
My "guess" is you are running into a particularly strict spam filter on the persons account. It could be a strict as to not deliver to the inbox unless your address is in the recipients address book.

There are many degrees between everything gets through to only those in the address book get through. Historically the most common stumbling block are email signatures, especially if you can send in web mail and get it delivered but not in Thunderbird. The issues with signatures are usually related to images for social media web sites as they have previously been used by spammers. But just the existence of a signature can be enough.

Then we have folks that are sending using their ISP server and an email address for another domain. This is a key indicator of SPAM. For instance sending for George@gmail.com using a outgoing mail server for Comcast, instead of the Gmail one.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: homecassey

content:
I doubt it is obvious to anyone. One of the big downsides of email is it actually has no guarantee of delivery. So once your provider accepts the email, tracking what and why can be most difficult to nigh on impossible.

Check in your Thunderbird account settings that there is no reply to address specified for the account. I have seen that cause issues, despite it's existence being perfectly acceptable in the standards. Unfortunately these huge players also play hard and fast with the rules. Their size lets them be the elephant in the room.

Send me an email to mattau at gmx dot com preferably close or the same as what is not being delivered, certainly from the same account. Perhaps I can see a clue in the message source.
